episode.title: Local 3489, United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO v. Usery

section.heading: Opinion Announcement of Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 75-657, Local Union 34-89 of the Steelworkers against Usery will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In this case, the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit held that the provision of the constitution of the United Steelworkers of America limiting eligibility for local union office to members of the local who had attended at least one half of the local's regular meetings for three years previous to the election of officers did not violate ยง401(e) Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act which provides that every union member in good standing shall be eligible to be a candidate in the whole office subject however to reasonable qualifications.
We disagree with the Court of Appeals in reserved.
We hold that where a meeting attendance requirement, as was the case of this one, resulted an exclusion of 96 and a half percent of petition of local's members from candidacy for office.

The requirement cannot be considered a reasonable qualification consistent with Title 4 goal and free and democratic union elections since the requirement having that result, restricts the free choice of the membership and selecting its leaders.
Mr. Justice Powell joined by Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissents and has filed a dissenting opinion.
